title: Are there any websites for downloading free books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Easily, if you go to a site that offers free books. There are many places you can go to find any number of books from throughout history all the way through to the 1940s and later. And if the author is dead and the work is out of copyright, you can download as many books as you want, all for free. However, if the books are still in print and in copyright, you will be breaking the law. People who download books without paying the author are stealing that author’s work. If everyone does that, no author will be able to afford to live. Of course, you may not be over worried about that. Still, here’s another little point. All the firms providing free downloads are, of course, breaking the law. They are deliberately infringing the author’s copyright. They are happy to do so because most of these firms are criminal gangs in their own right. They will happily promise to download a book to you, Some may ask for your credit card details, just as a proof of your ID. If you give them your card details, you will almost certainly be robbed. But even if you don’t give them your card details, usually such companies will be scamming you, not providing a download, but instead loading malware on your computer. This will invisibly hunt around your hard drive and find all your details for ID theft. Many will also hunt down your bank account and details. The short answer is, if you go to illegal sites that are providing criminal services, you can expect to be robbed. And to be frank, if you want to go to the trouble of depriving authors of their income, you deserve it.

Go to your local library. Most subscribe to services like Overdrive, so that they can loan out ebooks. Go to promotional sites, where authors give away copies to get reviews or to build a fan base. Instafreebie is one. Great deals on bestsellers you'll love has good deals, and giveaways, too. Go to sites where writers who are starting out offer their early works for free, to build up a fan base. There are dozens of them. What you don’t want to do is pirate books. Think about it: these people have no problem taking the money out of the hands of the people who create the work that they love. Why would they have a problem with stealing your id, or putting malware on your computer, etc? You’re not a friend, nor do you do anything they like. You’ve got to be lower on their priority list, than the authors/musicians/etc. And, let’s face it: piracy is defined by taking away the ONLY thing that lets authors, actors, and others make some return on the time and money that they’ve put into making the stuff you want. That is, indeed, theft. Do the right thing, and get books legally.

I assume you are talking about LEGALLY downloading books for free? Mercedes R. Lackey has given 3 good links below where out-of-copyright books can be found. For a book to be out of copyright, its author has to have been dead for 70 years. And then there are the giveaways from companies like Amazon, Smashwords etc. Just Google free ebooks. Of course, a retailer must have a reason for giving away current books for nothing; it might that is what the book is worth… You can pirate books but I advise against it. Firstly, you are only saving yourself a small amount and often getting a poor quality product. And secondly, it’s stealing coffee out of the mouths of impoverished authors like me (yes, roughly two ebooks purchased will buy me a coffee - but no cookie to go with it). I’m sure you don’t want to do that.

That depends, what are you looking for exactly? If you’re looking for sites to let you illegally download ebooks I can’t help you. Depending on the book you’re looking for though you may have some options. The library in my town uses Overdrive and Hoopla. Overdrive (Ocean State Libraries eZone) lets users download ebooks for 21 days. At the end of the 21 days the file will automatically lock and you won’t be able to access it again. If you weren’t done you’d have to re-download it. Hoopla (https://www.hoopladigital.com/)lets you borrow a set number of titles per month. This service focuses more on other media (movies, CD’s) but has some books as well. These are the services that allow you to borrow ebooks at no cost. Some companies like Amazon have a subscription service where you can read select ebooks from their catalog, but you need to pay for the service. If you’re looking for something to read for fun or a school reading assignment these might be helpful.
Project Gutenberg Many Books Internet Archive

Well, if you are not very interested to respect the legal property right, you’ll find a lot of free books on scribd.com, archive.org, libgen, globalgreyebooks, foulabook.com, torrents, etc. If you want legal books for free, you’ll find many sites too; but in big, they could be quite boring and maybe…useless. Also, I remember that the one who puts on web a book is responsible for some potential violation on property right. So, you can analyse the situation and make a decision. Ps: I’m sure that you’ll find many information on this subject quering Quora.

There are many web sites that will enable you to download free ebooks. Some are safe and reputable; some are not. I’ll suggest a good one to get you started. It is the Open Library. Their URL is Welcome to Open Library They have ebooks you can download and keep and they have ebooks you can borrow and read. (They expire at the end of the loan period.) They have fiction, non-fiction, new titles, classics, general books, specialized books, books for adults, books for children. Visit them. Go to their Help pages to learn how to use them efficiently. Use your email address and any password to get a library card, and enjoy their services.

I like using Bookbub. Go to the website, sign up, and everyday Bookbub will send you a list of low cost or free titles in genres that you like. Don't get carried away and grab every free book ever. Look to see how many likes the titles have received on Amazon, and/or whether they have been well reviewed on Library Journal, Kirkus, or other respectable review sources. Many books are free but not worth your time. ;-)

Use IRC. Textual 5 in Mac and MIRC for Windows. The server that works the best afaik is IRC.irchighway.net The channel - #ebookz. Using the @search option in the text box of the channel followed by either the author name or book title sends you a text file containing the names of the people serving, the file, format and size. Select the particular line you want, excluding the file size information and paste it into the text box of the channel. The book will download to your machine usually zippers or far. Unzip / unrar and it's ready to read.
